part.title: What does RES want?
part.para: RES is primarily a high-level index of the data it has ingested. It is only interested in a few key types of resource, properties and relationships. If you want to publish data which RES can index effectively, it helps to understand how the index divides the world into four broad categories of resource:

listitem.para: Real-world things (physical and abstract; people, physical objects, places, events etc.)
Creative works (novels, paintings, songs, photographs etc.)

Note that creative works are a subclass of real-world things. Unlike real-world things, they are typically about (depict, describe, have as a subject) other real world things. By contrast, a building or a person isn't normally about anything else.

Examples in the real world are entries in a library catalogue, or the text on a card next to a museum exhibit. This includes documents about real-world things. (Note that for a web page about some thing, the text of that page is the document, in isolation from its representation as HTML.) RES will only index data in documents which are openly-licensed.
Digital assets (digital images, text files, videos, audio files)

These are digital representations of things. RES is mostly interested in files which represent creative works: for example, a digital image file representing a photograph; a PDF file representing a novel; or an audio file representing a sound recording.

part.para: To produce minimal RES-friendly data, you need to organise your resources into these categories and define the relationships between them. The following diagram summarises the structure RES is looking for:

The next section shows how to fit data from the example web page to these resource categories.

section.title: Extracting things from the web page
section.para: Using the four categories above, the museum identifies a minimal set of resources which are useful to RES:

listitem.para: This is a real-world thing, the actual physical helmet in the museum's collection.

para.emphasis: The photograph taken by Vlad Dracula

listitem.para: The photograph is a creative work with the helmet as its subject.

para.emphasis: A JPEG file of the photograph

listitem.para: This is a digital asset which represents the photograph.

para.emphasis: One or more documents which contain the data

listitem.para: These are RDF documents which describe the helmet, the photograph, and the JPEG file. They also describe themselves: e.g. their licence, author, modification date. The museum has decided to publish its documents under an Open Government licence, which is acceptable to RES. See the full list in the section about licensing.

section.para: Having decided which resources to model, the next step is to choose URIs for each of them, covered in the next section.
